predicted_summary.wugwATSS-led(on-unsimp: Directs the Secretary of Commerce to: (1) make an injury determination in an antidumping or countervailing duty investigation initiated under this Act; or (2) determine whether an industry in the United States is being threatened with material injury. Authorizes a civil action in a United States district court.Directs the Commission to make a determination within 30 days after an initial investigation that resulted in an antidumping or countervailing duty order being terminated or suspended, and to issue a final determination within 60 days after the initial review.Directs the Commission to conduct an investigation and compile evidence with respect to the petition in the same manner and to the same extent as if an election had not been made.Requires an order issued by the International Trade Commission (ITC) to be appealed to a united States court of appeals. (Sec. 3) Sets forth precedential effect requirements for such proceedings.Sets forth certain procedural requirements for a civil action against a defendant.Directs the Commission to make a final determination within 45 days after a complaint has been filed regarding material injury, or the establishment of an industry in the united states is materially retarded, by reason of imports of the subject merchandise and that imports of such merchandise are not negligible.Requires the court to make a final determination regarding the likelihood of continuation or recurrence of material injury under this Act before the later of the calendar year.Amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to: (1) require a court to issue an injury determination within 30 days after the date on which the injury determination was first made; and (2) allow a jury to determine the award of a criminal penalty. (3) In the case of a party seeking revocation of an order or termination of a suspended investigation, the court shall seek review in the district court that made the original injury determination.Directs the Secretary of Commerce to: (1) notify the appropriate U.S. Trade Representative of the proposed remedies, antidumping duty investigations, antiduty investigations, countervailing duty reviews, and other measures applicable to goods from Argentina and Mexico on or after the date of the enactment of this Act; (2) report to the appropriate United States district court with respect to goods imported from Argentina or Mexico on such date; and (3) advise the appropriate International Trade Organization (ITO) of the amendments made by this Act.
predicted_summary.wugNATSS-led(on-unsimp: Unfair Foreign Competition Act of 2007 - Amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to direct the Department of Commerce (DOC) to: (1) investigate a possible antidumping or countervailing duty (D antidumping) violation in order to determine whether an industry in the United States is materially injured or disabled, or (2) is threatened with material injury, or is substantially retarded by reason of imports, or sales (or the likelihood of sales) for importation of the subject merchandise.Prohibits an election under this Act in order to determine whether revocation of the antidumping or countervailing duty order or termination of the investigation suspended would likely lead to continuation or recurrence of material injury based on the standards set forth.Requires the Commission to conduct an investigation and compile evidence with respect to the petition in the same manner and to the same extent as if an election had not been made.The following rules apply to actions initiated under this title: (1) appeal; and (2) hearings.Requires a court to issue a preliminary order that contains a determination of whether there is a reasonable cause of action.Requires the court to make a preliminary determination within 45 days after a complaint has been filed to determine whether an industry in the United States is materially retarded, by reason of imports of the subject merchandise, or is not negligible.Requires the court to make a final determination regarding the likelihood of continuation or recurrence of material injury before the later of such a time frame.Amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to: (1) allow a party seeking revocation of an order or termination of a suspended investigation to seek review in the district court that made the original injury determination; and (2) require such parties to file a judicial determination of injury within 30 days.Directs the Secretary of State to notify the appropriate officials of the North American Free Trade Agreement (North America) of the amendments made by this Act and that the United States district courts be treated as competent authorities for purposes of injury determinations under title XVIII of the Tariff Act of 1930.

predicted_summary.wugwATSS-led(on-unsimp: Substance Abuse Prevention and Treatment Enhancement Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to establish designated programs for the prevention and treatment of substance abuse.Designates an award recipient and recipient of federal financial assistance under a designated program.Voucherized Assistance Programs (EDAP) are programs in which the beneficiary is given a document or other authorization that may be used to pay for program services. Programs are programs that provide counseling, substance abuse, or preventive services regarding such abuse under specified circumstances.Prohibits the designation of any public or private entity as a program participant or subaward recipient regardless of whether the entity provides program services or not. Allows religious organizations to be program participants on the same basis as any other nonprofit private provider without impairing the religious character of such organizations or religious organizations.Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to: (1) make religious organizations eligible to be program participants on the basis of their religious character and freedom; and (2) ensure that such organizations retain their independence from federal, state, and local government (local government) and control over the definition, development, practice, and expression of such religious beliefs.Requires religious organizations to:  (1) alter its organizational structure; (2) remove religious art, icons, scripture, or other symbols; and (3) make such organization's religious beliefs and practices subject to applicable federal or State law or regulation.Requires an alternative entity to arrange for the individual to receive program services through an alternative provider.Requires a program beneficiary to: (1) participate actively in religious practice, worship, and instruction; and (2) follow rules of behavior devised by the organizations that are religious in content or origin.Directs the use of such funds for religious purposes only if the beneficiary is a program participant or a program beneficiary of a specified program.Prohibits state or local governments from imposing religious educational qualification requirements on providers of drug treatment programs, including religious organizations, in order to ensure the effectiveness of such programs.Directs the Secretary to waive any educational qualification imposed on an individual religious organization if: (1) the religious organization has failed to demonstrate empirically that the educational qualifications are necessary to the successful operation of a drug treatment program; and (2) the state or local government has not demonstrated empirically, that such qualification is necessary to a program's successful operation.
predicted_summary.wugNATSS-led(on-unsimp: Faith-Based Drug Treatment Enhancement Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to: (1) make awards of federal financial assistance to public or private entities for the purpose of preventing or treating substance abuse; and (2) establish designated programs for the prevention and treatment of substance abuse.Designates an award recipient and a program beneficiary. Designates a public or private entity that has received an award under a designated program (whether the award is a designated direct award or a designated subaward). Designates recipients of specified financial assistance through specified programs. Designers of specified programs may receive a grant, cooperative agreement, contract, or voucherized assistance.Requires religious organizations to participate in or be reimbursed by the program beneficiary for program services.Requires religious organizations to be program participants on the same basis as any other nonprofit private provider without impairing the religious character of such organizations or their program beneficiaries.Provides that neither the federal government nor a state receiving funds under such programs shall discriminate against an organization that is or applies to be a program participant on the basis that the organization has a religious character.Requires a religious organization to: (1) alter its form of internal governance; or (2) remove religious art, icons, scripture, or other symbols in order to be a program participant.Requires religious organizations to provide program services through an alternative provider if they are providing services pursuant to a voucherized assistance program.Requires any religious organization that is a program participant to be subject to Federal financial assistance to account requirements for the use of funds provided under such funds.Directs the State or local government to segregate federal funds from state or local public funds for purposes of carrying out such program.Requires States or local governments to establish formal educational qualification requirements for counselors and other personnel in drug treatment programs.Provides for the Secretary to waive any educational qualification for an individual religious organization if: (1) the religious organization has a prior successful drug treatment for at least three years; (2) the organization has effectively barred such religious organization from becoming a program provider; and (3) the state or local government has failed to demonstrate empirically that the educational qualifications are necessary to the successful operation of a drug treatment program.

predicted_summary.wugwATSS-led(on-unsimp: Amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal the federal retail excise tax on new heavy trucks, tractors, and trailers. Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress on:  (1) the cost of new heavy-duty trucks and tractors and trailers in 2016 and 2017, and (2) the average retail price for such trucks and trailers is $175,921; (3) the Federal Retail excise tax is the highest percentage rate in the history of the tax.Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) final rules establishing the phase 2 emissions standards for medium and heavy-duty engines and vehicles, and final rulemaking to establish the fuel economy standards for them, will add up to approximately $12,000 to the price of new heavy- duty trucks; and (1) in addition to the additional federal excise tax on new heavy trucks, tractors, and trailers, the Department of Transportation (DOT) will add $6,683 to the average price of a new heavy duty truck.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal the excise tax on heavy trucks and trailers.Amends the Federal Emergency Management Act of 1933 to: (1) allow the use of such vehicles for the operation of construction, manufacturing, processing, farming, mining, drilling, timbering, or similar operation only if the operation is unrelated to transportation on or off the public highways; and (2) require such vehicles to be maintained in good repair and maintained by the Federal Highway Administration (FHSA) for at least 30 days.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) make sales and installations free of tax under this Act; and (2) make such sales and installation subject to tax. (Sec. 3) repeal the prohibition against sale, purchase, or installation of any item that is not expressly prohibited by this Act.
predicted_summary.wugNATSS-led(on-unsimp: Heavy Truck, Tractor, and Trailer Retail Im Im excise tax Repeal Act of 2017   This bill amends the Federal retail excise tax (START) to: (1) increase the cost of new heavy-duty trucks, tractors, and trailers, and discourage the replacement of older, less environmentally clean and less fuel economical vehicles; (2) repeal the federal ad valorem excise tax, which was first levied by Congress in 1917 to help finance America's involvement in World War I i; (3) increase in-use, heavy truck, tractor, and trailer retail prices by $175,921; and (4) reduce the replacement age of such vehicles by 25 years.Amends the Environmental Protection Agency's model year 2002-2010 tailpipe emissions rules to: (1) establish greenhouse gas emissions standards for medium and heavy-duty engines and vehicles; (2) establish requirements for the fuel economy of new trucks and buses; (3) establish a regional EPA-department of transportation fuel economy rules that will add up to approximately $6,683 to the average truck price; (4) implement federal retail excise tax on certain new heavy trucks, tractors, and trailers; (5) implement a federal retail tax on new heavy truck sales based on annual sales; and (6) repeal of the federal diesel fuel tax, based on sales, on federal retail sales.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to:  (1) repeal the excise tax on heavy trucks and trailers, and (2) replace it with a new revenue mechanism to protect the Highway Trust Fund.Amends the Motor Vehicle Safety Act of 1965 to provide for the use of: (1) permanently mounted (by welding, bolting, riveting, or other means) machinery or equipment to perform a construction, manufacturing, processing, farming, mining, drilling, timbering, or similar operation if the operation of such machinery or machinery is unrelated to transportation on or off the public highways; and (2) a vehicle which, by reason of such special design, could not, without substantial structural modification, be used as a component of a vehicle designed to perform such function.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) repeal the tax deduction for sales and installations under this Act; and (2) make provisions for the sale of such equipment and services to the owner of specified vehicles and SUVs to persons who do not conform to specified tax brackets; (3) make such Act subject to excise tax on the gross motor vehicle and related motor vehicle parts; (4) repeal provisions establishing a special tax credit for the purchase and sale of vehicles and related equipment under specified tax-exempt categories; (5) extend such Act's authority to extend the tax exemption through the end of 2017 for sales or installations on or after the date of the introduction of this Act.

predicted_summary.wugNATSS-led(on-unsimp: Pueblo of Isleta Settlement and Natural Resources Restoration Act of 2006 - Provides for the parties to settle their claims under the isleta jurisdictional act, the purposes of which are to improve drainage of the irrigated land, the health of the forest land, and other natural resources, and to settle all claims that were raised or could have been raised.Requires the Secretary to establish in the Treasury a trust fund to be named the Pueblo of Isleta Natural Resources Restoration Fund, consisting of: (1) such amounts as are transferred to the Fund; and (2) interest earned on investment of such amounts in the Fund.Directs the Secretary to distribute funds from the settlement fund to the Pueblo.Directs the Secretary to: (1) distribute funds to the Pueblo for drainage and remediation expenses; and (2) make such funds available for expenditure for drainage, remediation, expenses.Requires the restoration of land, natural resources, and cultural resources within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo to be funded through Federal funds.Requires the Pueblo to withdraw funds from the restoration fund on approval by the Secretary of a Tribal Management Plan (STP) in accordance with specified tribal management reform requirements.Requires the Secretary to submit to the Secretary an expenditure plan for any funds withdrawn from the Fund under this Act that the Pueblo does not withdraw.Requires the Secretary of the Interior to approve the Expenditure Plan if the Secretary determines that the plan is reasonable and consistent with this Act and the settlement agreement.Requires the Pueblo to file a joint stipulation for the entry of final judgment in the case of Pueblos of isleta v. predicted_summary.wugwATSS-led(on-unsimp: Requires the Administrator to develop and carry out a pilot program to serve as a national model for the restoration of urban watersheds and community environments.Requires the Administrator to:  (1) coordinate the restoration and protection efforts with other Federal, State, and local government programs and provide community involvement in the decisionmaking process; (2) assist in the establishment of measurable goals for such restoration; and (3) maintain annual program plans which provide for public input in the development of measurable environmental conditions.Directs the Administrator to:  (1) establish on-the-ground projects for restoration of the watershed to the extent they are unique or transferable to national audiences; and (2) maintain and enhance the biennial work plan for the anacostia river watershed. Directs Federal landholders, tribal governments, and the Environmental Protection Agency to participate in urban habitat improvement projects in the watershed on a demonstration basis.Requires the Administrator to work in coordination with other Federal agencies, particularly the Army Corps of Engineers, to identify projects and activities which are supportive of the goals of the pilot program.
predicted_summary.wugNATSS-led(on-unsimp: National Urban Watershed Model Restoration Act - Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to develop and carry out a pilot program to serve as a national model for the restoration of urban watersheds and community environments.The pilot program requires the Federal Landholders and Programmatic Agencies to: (1) support baseline monitoring efforts of State and local governments to determine key trends in ambient environmental conditions for the purpose of filling gaps in critical data about the environmental condition of the watershed; (2) develop and maintain environmental indicators in conjunction with interested public entities and ensure regular public reporting of these indicators; (3) develop consensus strategies for the restoration and protection of the Watershed in cooperation with other Federal, State, and local groups to address critical issues and needs; (4) maintain a biennial federal work planning process for federal landholders and programmatic agencies to identify specific opportunities and needs for federal activities in support of the pilot program's goals; (5) demonstrate new technologies and approaches which are promising to increase the public's participation in environmental and health risks.Requires the Administrator to set aside no less than $400,000 for each fiscal year to make grants to: (1) implement on the ground projects for stormwater management, combined sewer overflow control, floatables reduction, forest buffer restoration, and other activities being conducted under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act; (2) participate in the implementation of the regional action plan for toxics reduction and prevention in the watershed; and (3) maintain and enhance the biennial work plan for the Anacostia River watershed.Requires the Administrator of the Agency making such funds available to carry out the pilot program to: (1) work in coordination with other Federal agencies to identify projects and activities which are supportive of the goals; and (2) report to Congress on the implementation and results of such pilot program.
